30th quarter this year: 1.

When we went up to oil the bearings prior to the quarter, we noticed what appeared to be a timber shaft which rose the height of the intermediate chamber and continued several feet into the bell chamber above. What was it? A mystery indeed!

Having rung the quarter we left the church, and a backward glance from the churchyard gate revealed the answer to the great mystery. Of course! The shaft was for the weights which drive the sundial on the south wall of the tower!

First on handbells: 1.
Rung to fill in time until the pub opened.

methodSecond: (4m: 10 extents each of Grandsire St Simon's Bob and St Martin's Bob; 12 extents of Plain Bob)
footnotes: First peal: 6.
First peal of Doubles: 1,2,3,4.
By a resident YCG band.
On 8th attempt!

A bad start to the term! Having come last in the striking competition, we then proceeded to ring a raggerd quarter. Rung one week late for St George's Day, having finished all our exams. The Conductor had six exams in five days, ending with a nasty Commodity Markets paper which he thinks he has failed. 4 had a Calculus exam this morning which had complex numbers in it which 4 couldn't do. Treble went to a party before ringing, while the rest continplated ringing a quarter of minimus on the front four, but fiddled with the Twiddle Pins on the seventh instead. 5 keeps asking what day it is and 2 has repeatedly said: "we are all very tired". We got this after the thrid attempt which is probably a new record for us. About the only successful ringing we've had this evening was the 480 of Little Bob we glided through during the first attempt, however,switching to St Clements proved to be a bad idea as we fired out after the first lead. It all started in 1964........

Rung by a band of chemists to celebrate the completion of the conductors BSc Chemistry course yesterday. With special thanks to Dr J M Lynam who supervised the conductors BSc project; "radical" mechanisms in molybdenum alkyne chemistry which was awarded a first class mark.

methodSecond: (2*120 1*240 Bob Doubles 360 Bob Minor)
footnotes: Conducted by David Bryant - first performance as conductor while sitting on a table. The only proper ringing involved in our part of "Bong! Smack!", a piece (of what is questionable!) specially commissioned by the City of York Council and involving all seven rings of six or more bells within the walls, plus a number of "Digital Bell Towers". See bongsmack.com for further information on the concept behind the performance. Submitted on the basis that if we could have used the hour and a quarter allowed solely for proper ringing we could, if we'd rung the bells at Robert Lee speed, have rung two quarters. To celebrate the disinfection of the Arts Centre porch!
